title: A Lamborghini Veneno Sells for Record US$8.27 Million
text:
Text size

An ultra-rare Lamborghini Veneno was hammered down at CHF8.2 million (US$8.27 million), a new world record price for a Lamborghini, after a seven-minute bidding war at a Bonhams auction in Geneva, Switzerland, on Sunday.

The previous record was held by 1972 Lamborghini Miura SV, which went for €2.34 million (about US$2.55 million) at an auction in Paris in February 2017.

The Lamborghini Veneno, the only roadster of the nine “ultimate” Lamborghinis produced in 2014 to celebrate the 50th anniversary of the Italian marque, is finished in off-white with a beige interior and has only covered 325 kilometers (about 202 miles).

The bidding started at CHF3 million and attracted six enthusiastic collectors. It had a presale low estimate of CHF5.2 million.

It’s one of the 25 supercars—dubbed The Supercar Collection—offered for sale without reserve by the State of Geneva. The items were reportedly confiscated from Teodorin Nguema Obiang, vice president of Equatorial Guinea, who was indicted on corruption, and other charges.

In 2017, a French court handed him a three-year suspended jail term for corruption. This February, Swiss prosecutors dropped charges of financial wrongdoing against him but confiscated his luxury cars.

The 51-year-old Obiang is seen as the heir-apparent to his father Teodoro Obiang Nguema Mbasogo, who for 40 years has ruled Equatorial Guinea, a former Spanish colony located on the west coast of Central Africa.

A 2014 Koenigsegg One:1 from the collection was one of just six produced by the Swedish manufacturer and realized CHF4.6 million at the auction.

In total, the 25 lots fetched CHF23.4 million with a 100% sell-through rate. Proceeds from this sale will go to social projects in Equatorial Guinea.

Returning to Switzerland for the first time in 10 years, the Bonhams auction at Bonmont Golf & Country Club also featured more than 70 classic and collectors cars representing marques such as Aston Martin, Bentley, Bugatti, Ferrari, Koenigsegg, Lamborghini, Maserati, Mercedes-Maybach, and Porsche.

The sale totalled CHF36.7 million, with an 86% sell-through rate.
description: The auction of 25 supercars realized US$27 million, with proceeds going to social programs in Equatorial Guinea
